questions.text: A 24-Year-old primigravida with 36 weeks of gestation presents with reduced fetal movements since 1day. She has no comorbidities. Her previous lab investigations and usg are normal. On examination, P- 80/min, BP-130/78mmHg, RR-13/min, afebrile, saturation normal, pallor present. Abdominal examination shows fundus below xiphisternum, vertical lie, cephalic presentation, head engaged, FHR-140/min. NST was done and was reactive. The BPP score was calculated and was found to be 8. The management includes:
questions.correct_answer: B. Repeat Testing at weekly intervals
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Repeat Testing at weekly intervals Fetal Biophysical Profile (BPP)—considers several parameters. BPP using real-time ultrasonography has a high predictive value.

questions.text: A 25-Year-old Primigravida with 30 weeks of gestation presents a history of reduced fetal movements. She has no comorbidities. Her previous lab investigations and usg are normal. On examination, P-90/min, saturation normal, pallor +, afebrile, RR-12/min, BP-126/84mmHg. Abdominal examination shows fundus in-between umbilicus and xiphisternum, vertical lie, cephalic presentation, head not engaged, FHR-140/min. Fetal NST was normal. She was reassured and advised DFMC technique. True statements are:

options.label: A
options.text: Three counts each in 1hr duration (esp. one hour after each meal, breakfast, lunch & dinner)

options.label: B
options.text: The total count is multiplied by 4

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Fetal movement count—Any of the two methods can be applied: Daily fetal movement count (DFMC) : Three counts of 1-hour duration (morning, noon and evening) are recommended. The total counts multiplied by four gives daily (12 hour) fetal movement count (DFMC). If there is diminution of the number of “kicks” to less than 10 in 12 hours (or less than 3 in each hour), it indicates fetal compromise. Cardiff “count 10” formula : The patient counts fetal movements starting at 9 am. The counting comes to an end as soon as 10 movements are perceived . She is instructed to report the physician if: Less than 10 movements occur during 12 hours on 2 successive days o No movement is perceived even after 12 hours in a single day.

questions.text: A 28-Year-old G2P1 with 37weeks of gestation presents with history of reduced fetal movements since 1day. She is a case of type 2 DM and preeclampsia on treatment. Her previous usg are normal. On examination, P-90/min, BP-138/96mmHg, RR-14/min, normal saturation, afebrile, pallor +, B/L pedal edema upto ankle seen. Abdominal examination shows fundus in-between umbilicus and xiphisternum, vertical lie, cephalic presentation, head engaged, FHR- 170/min. The causes for fetal tachycardia could be: 1. Beta sympathomimetic administered to mother 2. Vagolytic given to mother 3. Maternal or fetal infection 4. Maternal anemia 5. Fetal anemia Select the correct answer from the given below code:

A 32-Year-old G2P1 with 17weeks of gestation comes to OBG OPD for regular ANC. Her previous lab investigations and usg are normal. She has no comorbidities. On examination, P-90/min, BP-126/78mmHg, RR-13/min, afebrile, saturation normal, pallor +. Second trimester scan was advised. Her MSAFP levels on examination were found to be elevated. The causes for this condition could be all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Down's syndrome Maternal serum alpha fetoprotein (MSAFP) : AFP is an oncofetal protein (molecular weight 70,000). It is produced by yolk sac and fetal liver. Highest level of AFP in fetal serum and amniotic fluid is reached around 13 weeks and thereafter it decreases. Maternal serum level reaches a peak around 32 weeks .

Highyeild:

MSAFP level is elevated in a number of conditions: wrong gestational age, open neural tube defects (NTDs), multiple pregnancy, Rh isoimmunization, IUFD, anterior abdominal wall defects and renal anomalies. Low levels are found in trisomies (Down’s syndrome), gestational trophoblastic disease

questions.text: A 36-Year-old woman pregnant at 6 weeks gestation presents to your office for prenatal care. She is interested in prenatal testing for genetic abnormalities. She read on the Internet that an ultrasound measurement of the neck of the fetus can be used in prenatal diagnosis. Which of the following is correct information to tell your patient regarding ultrasound measurement of the fetal nuchal translucency for prenatal diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a screening test for Down syndrome performed between 10 and 13 weeks of pregnancy.

options.label: B
options.text: It can be performed by anyone trained in basic fetal ultrasonography.

options.label: C
options.text: It should be offered only to pregnant women less than 35 years.

options.label: D
options.text: It can be performed at any gestational age.

questions.correct_answer: A. It is a screening test for Down syndrome performed between 10 and 13 weeks of pregnancy.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is a screening test for Down syndrome performed between 10 and 13 weeks of pregnancy. The ultrasound nuchal translucency (NT) is now appreciated as a sensitive marker for Down syndrome and other aneuploidies between 10 and 13 weeks. Outside that range, the nuchal translucency disappears. Blood-free β-hCG and PAPPA in the first trimester and double (AFP and hCG) or triple (AFP, hCG, and estriol at 15-20 weeks) evaluations are statistically comparable. The combination of nuchal translucency and first-trimester biochemistry will likely be the optimal approach. Biochemistry does not work well for multiple gestations.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: D Outside that range(10 to 13 weeks ), the nuchal translucency disappears. Option: B. Measurement of the nuchal translucency should be performed only by persons certified for the procedure. Option: C. Nuchal translucency screening may be used in women of all ages.

questions.text: A 42-Year-old had a baby with Down syndrome 10 years ago. She is anxious to know the chromosome status of her fetus in her current pregnancy. She is currently at 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following tests will provide the most rapid diagnosis of Down syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chorionic villus sampling Chorionic villi harvested at 10 to 13 weeks will provide the earliest diagnosis of Down syndrome out of the listed evaluation methods.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Amniocentesis, cystic hygroma aspiration, and CVS are techniques of obtaining fetal cells for cytogenetic analysis. Amniotic fluid cells (obtained by amniocentesis at 14-20 weeks) require tissue culture to obtain adequate cell numbers for analysis. Option: B. Maternal serum analyte analysis is used for screening otherwise low risk women for Down syndrome and is not indicated in this patient of advanced maternal age with a prior affected child. Option: D. Fetal cells obtained by percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS) or cystic hygroma aspiration may not be obtained early in the pregnancy.

questions.text: In a nondiabetic high risk pregnancy the ideal time for non stress test monitoring is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

72 hours Intervals between NST testing The interval between tests is arbitrarily set at 7 days. According to ACOG, more frequent testing is advocated for women with post term pregnancy, type I diabetes mellitus, IUGR or gestational hypertension. In these circumstances some investigators recommend twice weekly (i.e. after 72 hours) with additional testing performed for maternal or fetal deterioration regardless of the time elapsed since the last test. Generally daily NST is recommended with severe preeclampsia remote from term.

questions.text: Increased acidosis and hypoxemia is associated with:

options.label: B
options.text: Increased fetal diastolic flow in the middle cerebral artery with absent diastolic flow in the aorta

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of the ‘notch’ in the uterine artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased fetal diastolic flow in the middle cerebral artery with absent diastolic flow in the aorta
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased fetal diastolic flow in the middle cerebral artery with absent diastolic flow in the aorta Doppler Study of Middle Cerebral Vessels: Normally the middle cerebral vessels have high resistance flow and are characterized by little diastolic flow. In case of IUGR a brain-sparing effect is seen with a reduction in the resistance indices in the middle cerebral vessels (i.e. increased flow) due to the shunting of blood to the brain in IUGR. Whereas in other areas (as aorta in the options) show decreased flow. Increased fetal diastolic flow in middle cerebral artery with absent diastolic flow in aorta implies fetal acidemia.

Extraedge:

As far as persistence of diastolic notch in uterine artery is concerned, it signifies pregnancies destined to develop preeclampsia.

questions.text: Sinusoidal heart rate pattern is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vasa previa Sinusoidal Pattern: Stable baseline heart rate of 120 to 160 beats/min with regular oscillations. Amplitude of 5 to 15 beats/min (rarely greater). Long-term variability frequency of 2 to 5 cycles per minute . Fixed or flat short-term variability. Oscillation of the sinusoidal waveform above or below a baseline. Absence of accelerations.

Highyeild:

Causes of Sinusoidal Pattern: Serious fetal anemia due to Rh-isoimmunization/rupture vasa previa / feto maternal hemorrhage / twin to twin transfusion. Drugs — Meperidine, morphine, alpha prodine and butorphanol. Amnionitis Fetal distress (+/–). Umbilical cord occlusion.

questions.text: Which is most significant finding in cardiotocography for detection of fetal hypoxia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Late deceleration It is one of those questions where if we keep searching for reference, we get more and more confused whereas the answer lies is front of our eyes and we all know it. The contraction stress test (CST) is based on the response of FHR to uterine contractions , with the premise that fetal oxygenation will be worsened. This results in late decelerations in an already suboptimally oxygenated fetus. The test requires 3 contractions in 10 minutes , a positive or abnormal test is when late decelerations occur with more than half of the contractions, suspicious with any late decelerations, and negative with no late decelerations. The most significant finding for hypoxia is late deceleration. Late decelerations are smooth falls in the FHR beginning after the contractions has started and ending after the contractions has ended. They are associated with fetal hypoxemia and potential for perinatal morbidity and mortality . Variable decelerations are abrupt in decline and return to baseline, vary in timing with the contractions, and usually represents cord compression. As far as sinusoidal pattern is concerned “Intrapartum sinusoidal fetal heart patterns were not generally associated with fetal compromise”.
